instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3476: What is 820-3476? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.D7010: What is D7010? Diode between ground and gate of Q7010 on 2013-2015 year retina model macbook pros, necessary for Q7010 to allow PPDCIN_G3H to flow through to PP3V42_G3H power supply input. When this diode dies or corrodes, PP3V42_G3H input will not have any voltage, and chargers will not turn on. This can often be the problem if a system only works with a knockoff charger/bench power supply. .
definitions.SMC_LID: What is SMC_LID? SMC_LID tells the machine the system is open when it is 3.3v to 3.4v, and closed when it is low such as 0v-0.6v. When this signal is low, the machine may go to sleep or have no backlight. .
definitions.PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT: What is PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT? PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT is a power rail that powers the LED light in the screen of the device that allows you to see what is on the screen. When this is low or missing, the screen will be dim..
definitions.LCDBKLT_EN_L: What is LCDBKLT_EN_L? This signal enables the backlight when it is low.  _L means the signal asserts itself when the voltage is low. This signal needs to be low to enable backlight. .

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message:
History:

Liquid damaged no green light.
Burnt KBD backlight connector J4915 (removed and area cleaned) - no short to ground on pin 3/4.
<DIODE>D7010</DIODE> missing (replaced) i've not idea why this was missing......
Now powering on with green light but no backlight. (Does boot up checked with microscope light there is an image present)


<TRANSISTOR>Q7700</TRANSISTOR> 
pin 4 12.58v
pin 3 12.46v
0v on output

<RESISTOR>R7701</RESISTOR>, <CAPACITOR>C7700</CAPACITOR>, <RESISTOR>R7702</RESISTOR> measuring fine. Replaced anyway as looked like they needed it.
<RESISTOR>R7700</RESISTOR> 0.2ohm

<CHIP>U7700</CHIP>
pin 11 12.46v (This is the problem i believe as it should pull <SIGNAL>LCDBKLT_EN_L</SIGNAL> low)
pin 17 (enable) 3.3v
pin 5&18 (power) 5v
<RESISTOR>R7731</RESISTOR> & <RESISTOR>R7732</RESISTOR> measure and look fine
<CAPACITOR>C7701</CAPACITOR> replaced 

tried replacing <TRANSISTOR>Q7700</TRANSISTOR> no change

with lcd connected.
<SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> 0v
<SIGNAL>PP5VR3V3_SW_LCD</SIGNAL> 5v
<SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> 3.4v
<SIGNAL>DP_INT_HPD</SIGNAL> 3.3v
<SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_PSR_EN</SIGNAL> 3.3v

<RESISTOR>R7750</RESISTOR>
<RESISTOR>R7751</RESISTOR> both 0.2ohm

<RESISTOR>R7752</RESISTOR>
<RESISTOR>R7753</RESISTOR> both 2.3k

pin 1 of LCD connector diode mode to ground: 1.1v


Does the same on two screens. (original screen quoted as working by customer, plus my known good screen - granted i haven't used it in a while). Relatively new to this so don't have any others to swap with at the mo.
Tried different LVDS cable for shits and giggles but no change.

i realise my issue is that <SIGNAL>LCDBKLT_EN_L</SIGNAL> (pin 3 of <TRANSISTOR>Q7700</TRANSISTOR>) is not being pulled to ground and therefore not turning on.  I've replaced the pre and post <TRANSISTOR>Q7700</TRANSISTOR> caps  (<CAPACITOR>C7700</CAPACITOR> & <CAPACITOR>C7701</CAPACITOR>) and the voltage divider to pin 3 as a caution. 
<CHIP>U7700</CHIP> has power pins 5&18 and enable pin 17 but is not pulling pin 11 (SD) to ground. 
Forgive my naivity but could i try jumping pin 3 of <TRANSISTOR>Q7700</TRANSISTOR> to ground just to see if it goes further ?

I am rather lost now as to where to follow this - any hints please ?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
[SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: Changed <CHIP>U7700</CHIP> from donor board. No change, re did the readings. Any other thoughts before trying another ? Possible to pull down <SIGNAL>LCDBKLT_EN_L</SIGNAL> to ground with a jumper just to test the rest up the chain?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: Did you test with a screen from the correct year? Verify continuity between pins 15/16 of <CHIP>U7700</CHIP> and LCD connector.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: Was indeed damaged trace. You can mark as closed. Thank you!
